message: You yourself must strive. The Buddhas only point the way.
Those who mistake the unessential to be essential and the essential to be unessential, dwelling in wrong thoughts, never arrive at the essential.
Whoever doesn’t flare up at someone who’s angry wins a battle hard to win.
Just as rain does not break through a well-thatched house, so passion never penetrates a well-developed mind.
Some do not understand that we must die, But those who do realize this settle their quarrels.
Whatever is not yours: let go of it. Your letting go of it will be for your long-term happiness & benefit.
Speak only endearing speech, speech that is welcomed. Speech, when it brings no evil to others, is a pleasant thing.
Ardently do today what must be done. Who knows? Tomorrow, death comes.
The good renounce (attachment for) everything. The virtuous do not prattle with a yearning for pleasures. The wise show no elation or depression when touched by happiness or sorrow.
Calm is his thought, calm his speech, and calm his deed, who, truly knowing, is wholly freed, perfectly tranquil and wise.
citation: Arahantavagga: The Arahant or Perfected One

message: Better it is to live one day virtuous and meditative than to live a hundred years immoral and uncontrolled.
Better it is to live one day wise and meditative than to live a hundred years foolish and uncontrolled.
Better it is to live one day strenuous and resolute than to live a hundred years sluggish and dissipated.
Better it is to live one day seeing the rise and fall of things than to live a hundred years without ever seeing the rise and fall of things.
All tremble at violence; all fear death. Putting oneself in the place of another, one should not kill nor cause another to kill.
All tremble at violence; life is dear to all. Putting oneself in the place of another, one should not kill nor cause another to kill.
One who, while himself seeking happiness, does not oppress with violence other beings who also desire happiness, will find happiness hereafter.
To avoid all evil, to cultivate good, and to cleanse one's mind — this is the teaching of the Buddhas.
He who checks rising anger as a charioteer checks a rolling chariot, him I call a true charioteer. Others only hold the reins.
Overcome the angry by non-anger; overcome the wicked by goodness; overcome the miser by generosity; overcome the liar by truth.
Let a man guard himself against irritability in speech; let him be controlled in speech. Abandoning verbal misconduct, let him practice good conduct in speech.
Let a man guard himself against irritability in thought; let him be controlled in mind. Abandoning mental misconduct, let him practice good conduct in thought.
One is not wise because one speaks much. He who is peaceable, friendly and fearless is called wise.
You yourselves must strive; the Buddhas only point the way. Those meditative ones who tread the path are released from the bonds of Mara.
All conditioned things are impermanent — when one sees this with wisdom, one turns away from suffering. This is the path to purification.
Good is virtue until life's end, good is faith that is steadfast, good is the acquisition of wisdom, and good is the avoidance of evil.
He who has renounced violence towards all living beings, weak or strong, who neither kills nor causes others to kill — him do I call a holy man.
He who is friendly amidst the hostile, peaceful amidst the violent, and unattached amidst the attached — him do I call a holy man.
Speak only the speech that neither torments self nor does harm to others. That speech is truly well spoken.
To have much learning, to be skillful in handicraft, well-trained in discipline, and to be of good speech — this is the greatest blessing.
To support mother and father, to cherish wife and children, and to be engaged in peaceful occupation — this is the greatest blessing.
Not to associate with the foolish, but to associate with the wise; and to honor those who are worthy of honor — this is the greatest blessing.
Just as a mother would protect her only child with her life even so let one cultivate a boundless love towards all beings.
citation: Karaniya Metta Sutta: The Discourse on Loving-kindness

message: Let him radiate boundless love towards the entire world — above, below, and across — unhindered, without ill will, without enmity.
citation: Karaniya Metta Sutta: The Discourse on Loving-kindness

message: We will develop and cultivate the liberation of mind by lovingkindness, make it our vehicle, make it our basis, stabilize it, exercise ourselves in it, and fully perfect it.
Think not lightly of good, saying, "It will not come to me." Drop by drop is the water pot filled. Likewise, the wise man, gathering it little by little, fills himself with good.
In this manner the world is afflicted by death and decay. But the wise do not grieve, having realized the nature of the world.
Hatred is never appeased by hatred in this world. By non-hatred alone is hatred appeased. This is a law eternal.
If a man going down into a river, swollen and swiftly flowing, is carried away by the current — how can he help others across
citation: Nava Sutta: The Simile of the Boat

message: ... they blame those who remain silent, they blame those who speak much, they blame those who speak in moderation. There is none in the world who is not blamed.
If with a pure mind a person speaks or acts happiness follows him like his never-departing shadow.
Just as a solid rock is not shaken by the storm, even so the wise are not affected by praise or blame.

The earth's sprinkled
 with rain, wind
  is blowing, lightning
 wanders the sky,
 but my thoughts are stilled,
 well-centered
 my mind.

Whatever living creatures there be, Without exception, weak or strong, Long, huge or middle-sized, Or short, minute or bulky, Whether visible or invisible, And those living far or near, The born and those seeking birth, May all beings be happy!
citation: Karaniya Metta Sutta: The Hymn of Universal Love

message: May rather skin, sinews and bones wither away, may the flesh and blood of my body dry up: I shall not give up my efforts so long as I have not attained whatever is attainable by manly perseverance, energy and endeavor!

When the crowded Vietnamese refugee boats met with storms or pirates, if everyone panicked all would be lost. But if even one person on the boat remained calm and centered, it was enough. It showed the way for everyone to survive.
Letting go gives us freedom, and freedom is the only condition for happiness. If, in our heart, we still cling to anything—anger, anxiety, or possessions—we cannot be free.
citation: Thich Nhat Hanh, The Heart of the Buddha's Teaching: Transforming Suffering into Peace, Joy, and Liberation

message: Many people think excitement is happiness...But when you are excited you are not peaceful. True happiness is based on peace.
citation: Thich Nhat Hanh, The Art of Power

message: Breathing in, I calm body and mind. Breathing out, I smile. Dwelling in the present moment I know this is the only moment.
If you love someone but rarely make yourself available to him or her, that is not true love.
Hope is important because it can make the present moment less difficult to bear. If we believe that tomorrow will be better, we can bear a hardship today.
citation: Thich Nhat Hanh, Peace Is Every Step: The Path of Mindfulness in Everyday Life

message: For things to reveal themselves to us, we need to be ready to abandon our views about them.
When you begin to see that your enemy is suffering, that is the beginning of insight
citation: Thich Nhat Hanh, Peace Is Every Step: The Path of Mindfulness in Everyday Life

message: When you love someone, you have to offer that person the best you have. The best thing we can offer another person is our true presence
citation: Thich Nhat Hanh, No Mud, No Lotus: The Art of Transforming Suffering

message: We are very good at preparing to live, but not very good at living. We know how to sacrifice ten years for a diploma, and we are willing to work very hard to get a job, a car, a house, and so on. But we have difficulty remembering that we are alive in the present moment, the only moment there is for us to be alive.
citation: Thich Nhat Hanh, Peace Is Every Step: The Path of Mindfulness in Everyday Life

message: Anxiety, the illness of our time, comes primarily from our inability to dwell in the present moment.
citation: Thich Nhat Hanh, The Heart of the Buddha’s Teaching: Transforming Suffering into Peace, Joy, and Liberation

message: The most basic condition for happiness is freedom. Here we do not mean political freedom, but freedom from the mental formations of anger, despair, jealousy, and delusion... As long as these poisons are still in our heart, happiness cannot be possible.
citation: Thich Nhat Hanh, Anger: Buddhist Wisdom for Cooling the Flames

message: You have to realize that happiness is not something you find at the end of the road. You have to understand that it is here, now.
citation: Thich Nhat Hanh, You Are Here: Discovering the Magic of the Present Moment

message: The truth is the truth, whether or not it is accepted by the majority. Therefore, I tell you children, it takes great courage to stand up for and protect what is right.
citation: Thich Nhat Hanh, Old Path White Clouds: Walking in the Footsteps of the Buddha

message: The mind is like a crazy monkey, which leaps about and never stays in one place. It is completely restless and constantly paranoid about its surroundings. The training, or the meditation practice, is a way to catch this monkey, to begin with. That is the starting point.
citation: Chogyam Trungpa, The Teacup & the Skullcup: Chogyam Trungpa on Zen and Tantra

message: Everything that occurs is not only usable and workable but is actually the path itself. We can use everything that happens to us as the means for waking up. We can use everything that occurs — whether it’s our conflicting emotions and thoughts or our seemingly outer situation — to show us where we are asleep and how we can wake up completely, utterly, without reservations.
citation: Pema Chödron, The Pocket Pema Chödron

message: When you are practicing Zazen, do not try to stop your thinking. Let it stop by itself. If something comes into your mind, let it come in, and let it go out. It will not stay long. When you try to stop your thinking, it means you are bothered by it. Do not be bothered by anything. It appears as if something comes from outside your mind, but actually it is only the waves of your mind, and if you are not bothered by the waves, gradually they will become calmer and calmer.
citation: Shunryu Suzuki, Zen Mind, Beginner's Mind

message: Leave your front door and your back door open. Allow your thoughts to come and go. Just don’t serve them tea.
citation: Shunryu Suzuki, quoted by David Chadwick, Crooked Cucumber: The Life and Zen Teaching of Shunryu Suzuk
